paragraph:
In attempting to judge the success of a
physical theory, we may ask ourselves two ques-
tions: (1) “Is the theory correct?’ and (2) “Is
the description given by the theory complete?”
It is only in the case in which positive answers
may be given to both of these questions, that the
concepts of the theory may be said to be satis-
factory. The correctness of the theory is judged
by the degree of agreement between the con-
clusions of the theory and human experience.
This experience, which alone enables us to make
inferences about reality, in physics takes the
form of experiment and measurement. It is the
second question that we wish to consider here, as
applied to quantum mechanics.

Whatever the meaning assigned to the term
complete, the following requirement for a com-
plete theory seems to be a necessary one: every
element of the physical reality must have a counter-
part in the physical theory. We shall call this the
condition of completeness. The second question
is thus easily answered, as soon as we are able to
decide what are the elements of the physical
reality.

The elements of the physical reality cannot
be determined by @ priori philosophical con-
siderations, but must be found by an appeal to
results of experiments and measurements. A
comprehensive definition of reality is, however,
unnecessary for our purpose. We shall be satisfied

seems to us that this criterion, while far from
exhausting all possible ways of recoghizing a

such way, whenever the conditions set down in

More generally, it is shown in quantum me-
chanics that, if the operators corresponding to
two physical quantities, say A and B, do not
commute, that is, if ABBA, then the precise
knowledge of one of them precludes such a
knowledge of the other. Furthermore, any
attempt to determine the latter experimentally
will alter the state of the system in such a way
as to destroy the knowledge of the first.

From this follows that either (1) the quantum-
mechanical description of reality given by the wave
function is not complete or (2) when the operators
corresponding to two physical quantities do not
commute the two quantities cannot have simul-
taneous reality. For if both of them had simul-
taneous reality—and thus definite values—these
values would enter into the complete description,
according to the condition of completeness. If
then the wave function provided such a complete
description of reality, it would contain these
values; these would then be predictable. This
not being the case, we are left with the alter-
natives stated.

paradoxes.full_sentence: From this follows that either (1) the quantum-mechanical description of reality given by the wave function is not complete or (2) when the operators corresponding to two physical quantities do not commute the two quantities cannot have simultaneous reality.
paradoxes.explanation: The paradox arises from the conflict between the completeness of the quantum-mechanical description of reality and the possibility of two physical quantities having simultaneous reality. If the quantum description is complete, it should be able to account for all physical phenomena, including the simultaneous reality of two quantities. However, if two quantities cannot have simultaneous reality, it implies that the quantum description is not complete.

paradoxes.full_sentence: For if both of them had simultaneous reality—and thus definite values—these values would enter into the complete description, according to the condition of completeness.
paradoxes.explanation: The paradox here is that if two quantities have simultaneous reality (and thus definite values), these values should be included in the complete description of reality. However, the quantum-mechanical description does not allow for simultaneous reality, suggesting a contradiction in the completeness of the description.

paradoxes.full_sentence: If then the wave function provided such a complete description of reality, it would contain these values; these would then be predictable.
paradoxes.explanation: The paradox arises from the conflict between the completeness of the wave function's description of reality and the predictability of the values of physical quantities. If the wave function provides a complete description, it should contain the values of all physical quantities, making them predictable. However, in quantum mechanics, these values are not always predictable, suggesting a contradiction in the completeness of the wave function's description.

paragraph:
Previously we proved that either (1) the
quantum-mechanical description of reality given
by the wave function is not complete or (2) when
the operators corresponding to two physical
quantities do not commute the two quantities
cannot have simultaneous reality. Starting then
with the assumption that the wave function
does give a complete description of the physical
reality, we arrived at the conclusion that two
physical quantities, with noncommuting oper-
ators, can have simultaneous reality. Thus the
negation of (1) leads to the negation of the only
other alternative (2). We are thus forced to
conclude that the quantum-mechanical descrip-
tion of physical reality given by wave functions
is not complete.

paradoxes.full_sentence: Starting then with the assumption that the wave function does give a complete description of the physical reality, we arrived at the conclusion that two physical quantities, with noncommuting operators, can have simultaneous reality.
terms_in_conflict: simultaneous reality of two physical quantities with noncommuting operators
paradoxes.explanation: The authors initially state that if the wave function provides a complete description of reality, then two physical quantities with noncommuting operators cannot have simultaneous reality. However, they then contradict this by stating that assuming the completeness of the wave function leads to the conclusion that these two quantities can indeed have simultaneous reality.

paradoxes.full_sentence: Thus the negation of (1) leads to the negation of the only other alternative (2).
paradoxes.explanation: The authors present a paradox where negating the first statement (that the wave function does not completely describe reality) leads to the negation of the second statement (that two physical quantities with noncommuting operators cannot have simultaneous reality). This is paradoxical because the authors initially presented these statements as mutually exclusive alternatives.

paragraph:
One could object to this conclusion on the
grounds that our criterion of reality is not suf-
ficiently restrictive. Indeed, one would not arrive
at our conclusion if one insisted that two or more
physical quantities can be regarded as simul-
taneous elements of reality only when they can be
simultaneously measured or predicted. On this
point of view, since either one or the other, but
not both simultaneously, of the quantities P
and Q can be predicted, they are not simultane-
ously real. This makes the reality of P and Q
depend upon the process of measurement carried
out on the first system, which does, not disturb
the second system in any way. No reasonable
definition of reality could be expected to permit
this.

paradoxes.full_sentence: On this point of view, since either one or the other, but not both simultaneously, of the quantities P and Q can be predicted, they are not simultaneously real.
paradoxes.explanation: The paradox arises from the idea that two quantities cannot be simultaneously real if they cannot be simultaneously predicted, even though prediction and reality are not necessarily linked.

paradoxes.full_sentence: This makes the reality of P and Q depend upon the process of measurement carried out on the first system, which does, not disturb the second system in any way.
paradoxes.explanation: The paradox here is that the reality of P and Q is made to depend on a measurement process that does not affect them, suggesting a disconnect between the process of measurement and the reality it is supposed to reflect.

paradoxes.full_sentence: No reasonable definition of reality could be expected to permit this.
paradoxes.explanation: The paradox is that a reasonable definition of reality is expected not to allow reality to depend on measurement, even though measurement is a common way of establishing reality in science.

While we have thus shown that the wave
function does not provide a complete description
of the physical reality, we left open the question
of whether or not such a description exists. We
believe, however, that such a theory is possible.
